reasoning: The critique targets a specific inferential step in the essay’s case that “linear (separable) unbounded views are fussy”: the move from separability to there being a single canonical parcel-level arrangement that must be replicated, implying extreme specificity. That step is part of the linear-view argument, so undermining it would meaningfully weaken (but not fully collapse) the overall “no easy eutopia” conclusion, which also relies on other routes (e.g., fat-tailed value-efficiency, many independent ‘fragility’ dimensions, and bounded-view fussiness). The objection is substantively strong as a logic point—separability/additivity does not entail uniqueness of the maximizing parcel-type and allows large families/plateaus of near-optima—so it undercuts the ‘single blueprint’ framing. However, it only partially refutes the essay’s linear-view fussiness claim, because the essay also argues (independently of uniqueness) that value-per-resource is likely highly concentrated/fat-tailed, which could still make the set of ≥50%-efficient parcel-uses small even if not unique. The critique is mostly correct, very clear, focused on one issue, and contains little dead weight.
title: Separable linear values do not imply a unique blueprint, enlarging the eutopia target
